Description: Terracotta figurine of woman, fragment: head and upper body of woman (Cybele?), wavy hair taken back off forehead, falling on either side of neck, stephane decorated with palmettes in relief, disc-earrings, wearing chiton and himation, arms bent forwards carrying small lion. Mouldmade, back left rough, body hollow, head probably solid, pinkish-buff fabric, traces of white slip and of red and blue paint. Soft, fine orange fabric with rare silver mica inclusions and a soapy texture.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Hellenion (Naukratis), Site 5 (Hogarth), 10 inches above the mud
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Dated c. 400 BC by Gutch (Gutch 1898-9, 84, pl. XII.74). Late 5th century BC parallel from Halicarnassus with similar soapy fabric (Higgins 1970, 422; GR 1857,1220.64) and again dated c. 300 BC (Burn and Higgins 2001, 2556, GR 1857,1220.65).
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 84, no. 74, pl. XII, no. 74)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.344) (Phase 3)
